study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether preoperative comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) and postoperative geriatric follow-up, including an exercise program, could counteract physical decline and improve quality of life in frail older patients undergoing surgery for colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it is designed to assess changes in physical performance (30-s chair stand test), health-related quality of life, physical strength, and other secondary endpoints in frail CRC patients receiving geriatric intervention and exercise versus standard care.
population_specificity: Frail older patients (≥65 years) undergoing surgical resection for primary colorectal cancer (CRC).
study_duration: Preoperative and postoperative intervention totaling 14 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and gait training with functional electrical stimulation (FES) improved walking speed and gait characteristics in subacute stroke patients compared to using either intervention alone.
results_summary: The combination of tDCS and FES improved gait regularity (measured by autocorrelation coefficients) compared to FES alone, but no significant effects were observed on walking speed or other gait parameters (harmonic ratio, root mean square).
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (n=34; mean age 72.5 years) with lower extremity paresis.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of intervention (tDCS+FES, tDCS, or FES) plus 40 minutes of conventional rehabilitation daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence and risk factors of subsequent vertebral fractures in patients with osteoporotic vertebral fractures (OVFs), including the impact on walking ability and other functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that 6.7% of patients experienced subsequent vertebral fractures within 48 weeks, with most occurring within 6 months. Patients with subsequent fractures had significantly lower walking ability scores and higher low back pain scores. Severe low back pain and soft brace use were associated with higher fracture risk, while rigid braces reduced risk.
population_specificity: Women aged 65-85 years with fresh osteoporotic vertebral fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether robot-assisted stair training (using PAAR or SCAR) integrated with conventional training improves gait recovery and independence in early stroke patients compared to conventional training alone.
results_summary: Both robot-assisted training groups (PAAR and SCAR) showed significant functional improvements, with SCAR enhancing gait independence and PAAR improving walking speed more than conventional training alone. All groups demonstrated clinically meaningful improvements in all outcome measures.
population_specificity: Sub-acute stroke survivors (within 2 months after stroke onset).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions (at least twice weekly, 30 minutes per session).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over several weeks (based on session frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of telerehabilitation, including walking-based exercise training, for people with chronic respiratory diseases compared to traditional in-person rehabilitation or no rehabilitation.
results_summary: Telerehabilitation, including walking exercises, showed similar outcomes to in-person rehabilitation for exercise capacity, quality of life, and breathlessness, with higher completion rates. It also improved exercise capacity compared to no rehabilitation, with no additional safety concerns.
population_specificity: Primarily individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (99% of participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise training component required, but exact walking dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Varied by study (not explicitly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if post-exercise central hemodynamics in CAD patients are affected by exercising in cold conditions.
results_summary: The study found that moderate-intensity walking (65-70% of HR) may influence central aortic blood pressure and wave reflection in CAD patients, though the abstract does not specify the direction or magnitude of these effects.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) (n=11).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sulodexide on diabetic complications, including its impact on walking limitations in peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: Sulodexide increased pain-free and maximal walking distance in peripheral arterial disease among diabetic patients, with no increased risk of adverse events compared to controls.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients (mean age 57 years; 63% male) with complications such as peripheral arterial disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 12-week stride walking exercise intervention on sleep quality, fatigue, and depression in postpartum women with poor sleep quality.
results_summary: The study found that the walking intervention significantly improved physical symptoms associated with sleep inefficiency at 4 weeks, but no significant differences were observed in fatigue or depression at 4 or 12 weeks compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Postpartum women with poor sleep quality (PSQS score ≥16) in southern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: 20-30 minutes of stride walking (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of two lobule-specific bilateral cerebellar transcranial direct current stimulation (ctDCS) montages to facilitate overground walking in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant effects of ctDCS montages on gait parameters ('Step Time Affected Leg' and '%Stance Time Unaffected Leg') and correlated these changes with mean electric field strength in cerebellar lobules. Both montages improved clinical outcome measures, suggesting potential benefits for gait in chronic stroke.
population_specificity: Ten chronic post-stroke male subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key factors associated with positive improvements in walking speed among older adults undergoing hospital-based rehabilitation.
results_summary: Better cognition (higher Mini Mental State Examination scores) and longer rehabilitation stays were associated with improved walking speed, while other factors like age, frailty, and comorbidities showed no significant association.
population_specificity: Older adults (median age 80.9 years) admitted to geriatric rehabilitation wards with a goal to improve walking.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved additional daily physical therapy focused on mobility).
study_duration: Duration of rehabilitation stay varied (specific length not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of immersive VR-assisted rehabilitation versus traditional rehabilitation for gait recovery in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study evaluated multiple gait and motor function outcomes but did not report specific results in the abstract; it emphasized the potential of VR-assisted rehabilitation to improve patient engagement and clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty-six stroke patients within 1 month of initial stroke.
effective_dosage: VR-assisted training (30 min) 5 days/week for the VRT group; functional gait rehabilitation training (30 min) 5 days/week for the non-VRT group.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention with follow-ups at 3 weeks and 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of n-3 PUFA supplementation on muscle mass and function, including walking speed, in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of n-3 PUFA supplementation on walking speed. Grip strength improved significantly, but muscle mass parameters showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intravenous and periarticular administration of corticosteroids on pain control during walking and other postoperative outcomes following total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: Periarticular injection of corticosteroids provided significantly better pain control during walking at 24 hours postoperatively compared to intravenous administration, though nausea control was similar between groups. Intravenous administration showed better anti-thromboembolic effects, but deep venous thrombosis incidence was low in both groups.
population_specificity: 100 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Intravenous group: 10 mg dexamethasone 1 hour before and 24 hours after surgery; periarticular group: 40 mg triamcinolone acetonide during surgery.
study_duration: 24 hours post-surgery for primary outcomes, with follow-up at 48 hours and 1 week for secondary markers.

study_goal: The researchers sought to identify mechanisms contributing to rural women's physical activity and diet changes after participating in a multilevel community-randomized trial focused on walking and healthy behavior.
results_summary: The SHHC intervention increased social support from friends for physical activity and healthy eating, which marginally mediated the intervention effects for walking metabolic equivalent minutes per week, explaining 40.5% of the total effect.
population_specificity: Overweight, sedentary midlife and older women (mean age 59) from 16 rural towns in Montana and New York.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 30% ethanolic extract on locomotive syndrome in an aging population.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention on Walking or locomotive syndrome.
population_specificity: Aging individuals with locomotive syndrome.

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the prevalence and factors associated with depressive symptoms among postpartum mothers in southern Nepal, including the impact of walking distance to health facilities.
results_summary: The study found that postpartum mothers whose nearest health facility was located more than 60 minutes of walking distance had significantly higher odds of depressive symptoms (aOR = 4.52). Walking distance was identified as an independent predictor of postpartum depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Postpartum mothers attending a child immunization clinic in southern Nepal.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to diagnose and describe the clinical presentation of pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (PVOD) in a patient with exertional dyspnoea.
results_summary: The study identified PVOD in a 28-year-old woman through imaging and hemodynamic measurements, revealing severe pulmonary hypertension and right heart enlargement. A mutation in the eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2 alpha kinase 4 was also found.
population_specificity: A 28-year-old woman with exertional dyspnoea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of implicit versus explicit motor learning approaches in improving walking speed for chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found no statistically or clinically significant differences in walking speed improvement between implicit and explicit motor learning interventions post-intervention or at follow-up. Both approaches showed similar efficacy in improving walking speed for chronic stroke survivors.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (mean age 66.4 years, mean time post-stroke 70.1 months, mean walking speed 0.7 m/s).
effective_dosage: 9 training sessions (30 minutes each) over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of SARC-F, SARC-CalF, SARC-F+EBM, and Ishii test as screening tools for sarcopenia in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc).
results_summary: The study found that SARC-CalF, SARC-F+EBM, and Ishii test performed better than SARC-F alone for sarcopenia screening in SSc patients, with SARC-F+EBM being the most suitable for routine care. The Ishii test showed the highest sensitivity but slightly lower specificity.
population_specificity: 94 patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of the START app, which integrates Self-Determination Theory principles and behavior change techniques, in increasing walking among inactive office employees.
results_summary: The app was rated favorably for quality, and frequent self-monitoring of step counts positively predicted weekly step counts. App features like reminders and motivational messages were perceived to help users achieve goals by enhancing competence and self-monitoring.
population_specificity: Insufficiently physically active office employees (mean age 44.21 ± 10.95 years, BMI 29.02 ± 5.65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fall prevention interventions, including walking-based programs, are effective in reducing falls and improving balance, mobility, and lower limb strength in people post-stroke.
results_summary: The study found no intervention significantly more effective than placebo in preventing falls, with most showing little effect on fall risk factors, except combined treadmill and overground walking, which improved mobility.
population_specificity: Individuals in the post-acute and chronic stages of stroke (1,352 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) on inspiratory muscle strength and exercise capacity (measured via 6-minute walking test) in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that 8 weeks of incremental IMT at 40% of maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) significantly improved inspiratory muscle strength (SNIP and MIP) and exercise capacity (6MWT distance) in T2DM patients compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and no prior cardiopulmonary or neuromuscular diseases or back pain.
effective_dosage: Incremental inspiratory muscle training at 40% of MIP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and sensitivity of an unsupervised, video game-based digital therapeutic (EVO Monitor) for assessing cognition in multiple sclerosis patients.
results_summary: Participants with multiple sclerosis and cognitive impairment performed worse in EVO Monitor compared to those without impairment, and performance correlated with standard cognitive and walking speed measures. The tool showed associations with brain volumetric data, suggesting clinical utility.
population_specificity: 100 people with multiple sclerosis (33 with cognitive impairment, 67 without) and 24 adults without multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of dual-task gait training (DTGT) and single-task gait training (STGT) on cognitive-motor dual-task interference after stroke.
results_summary: Both DTGT and STGT improved single and dual-task gait speed but did not change the relative amount of dual-task interference. Subgroup analysis suggested potential benefits of DTGT for those with greater baseline interference.
population_specificity: 36 adults within 3 years of stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term clinical outcomes of two total knee replacement systems (Sanat Swing® and NexGen®) in terms of functionality, pain relief, and mobility, including walking ability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain levels, walking distance, or other functional outcomes between the two knee implant systems after 10 years. Sanat Swing showed a slightly shorter operation time but comparable safety and efficacy to NexGen.
population_specificity: 189 patients (93 males, 96 females; mean age 68 years) who underwent total knee replacement between 2008 and 2010.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and postoperative activities between two surgical techniques (arthroscopic ALL repair alone vs. ALL repair with IER reinforcement) for chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in postoperative activities, JSSF scale, or SAFE-Q scores between the two surgical groups, though the IER reinforcement group had a longer surgical time.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic ankle instability who underwent arthroscopic repair (excluded those with additional ankle lesions or short follow-up).
study_duration: Follow-up period of at least 1 year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cardiac rehabilitation (exercise + education), exercise only, and usual care on functional walking capacity, risk factor control, and morbidities in patients with coronary artery disease.
results_summary: The cardiac rehabilitation program significantly improved functional walking capacity, reduced low-density lipoprotein and depressive symptoms, and decreased morbidities compared to exercise only and usual care after one year. Exercise alone also improved walking capacity but was less effective than the full rehabilitation program.
population_specificity: 492 male and female patients (aged 45-73) with coronary artery disease post-myocardial infarction, percutaneous coronary intervention, or coronary artery bypass grafting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the frequency and pattern of subtle functional disorders, particularly walking impairments, in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) who show no overt signs of disability in the early phase of the disease.
results_summary: The study found that 90% of PwMS showed reduced walking endurance, 57% had abnormal perceived walking ability, and 48% had balance impairments. Factors like balance and fatigue were significant predictors of perceived walking ability, while endurance had minimal impact.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) with an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score ≤2.5 and disease duration ≤5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of wearable activity monitors (WAMs) as a feedback and monitoring tool in home-based exercise programs for patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: WAM interventions improved walking ability (e.g., maximum walking distance, claudication distance, six-minute walk distance), increased daily walking activity, enhanced cardiovascular metrics, and improved quality of life. However, studies were limited by small sample sizes, short durations, and lack of consensus on outcome reporting.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an office-based, multicomponent activity intervention on visceral adipose tissue (VAT) in sedentary office workers.
results_summary: The study examined how office-based activity influences VAT, but specific results regarding the effectiveness of walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Sedentary office workers with a mean BMI of 31.4 (SD 4.4) kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of early postacute multidisciplinary rehabilitation, including walking, in improving physical and cognitive outcomes for severe or critical COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: The study found that multidisciplinary rehabilitation significantly improved lung function and physical performance, including a mean increase of 176 meters in six-minute walking distance, though some patients still had residual neurological symptoms and limited diffusion capacity.
population_specificity: 23 subjects discharged after severe to critical COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of home-based stair walking versus gym-based continuous stair climbing on cardiovascular and metabolic risk factors in sedentary women.
results_summary: The study found that walking up and down stairs at home improved aerobic fitness, serum lipids, body composition, fasting blood glucose, and resting cardiovascular variables, though direct comparison with gym-based stair climbing was not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Sedentary women (average age 31.7 ± 1.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of specialised orthotic care compared with usual orthotic care in adults with slowly progressive neuromuscular disorders (NMDs).
results_summary: The study will assess primary endpoints such as gross walking energy cost and achievement of personal goals, along with secondary endpoints including walking speed, gait biomechanics, stability, and falls. Results are pending as the study is prospective and not yet completed.
population_specificity: Adults with slowly progressive neuromuscular disorders (NMDs).
study_duration: 6 months (with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and classify outcome measures used to evaluate lower limb orthotic management post-stroke and determine which measures recorded the largest effect sizes.
results_summary: The study found that mobility-related outcome measures, particularly the 10-metre Walk Test, Functional Reach Test, and Physiological Cost Index, recorded large effect sizes in evaluating orthotic management post-stroke. The most frequently represented ICF codes were related to walking (d450) and moving around (d455).
population_specificity: Individuals post-stroke who received lower-limb orthotic interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait parameters between individuals with Parkinson's disease (on medication) and healthy controls during self-selected walking speed.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with Parkinson's disease exhibited reduced walking speed, stride length, swing time, and hip excursion compared to healthy controls, along with higher cadence and double support time. Differences were smaller for treadmill walking but still significant.
population_specificity: 1510 individuals with Parkinson's disease (on medication) and 1517 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether volunteer-supported outdoor walking improves physical function and quality of life in older people with inadequate activity levels.
results_summary: The study expects the intervention to improve overall health status across various outcomes, including physical function and quality of life, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals older than 65 years living in the community or nursing homes.
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 30-50 minutes per session (outdoor walk or equivalent indoor activity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare implant failure rates, bone union rates, and walking ability between early weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing groups following intramedullary nailing for tibial shaft fractures.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in implant failure, bone union rates at six months and one year, or walking ability between the early weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing groups. Early weight-bearing was not associated with increased harm.
population_specificity: 263 patients with tibial shaft fractures treated surgically, excluding polytrauma patients and those lost to follow-up.
effective_dosage: Partial weight-bearing walking within four weeks (EWB group) vs. no weight-bearing for more than four weeks (NWB group).
study_duration: Follow-up at six months and one year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the evidence on the safety and efficacy of stromal vascular fraction (SVF) injections for treating knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The majority of patients reported improvements in pain, range of motion, functional ratings, and walking distance. No major donor-site morbidity was reported, with only one case of knee joint infection and no tumor formation.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (200 patients, 290 knees).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of unstructured mobility programs (primarily walking) on physical activity, physical function, length of stay, and quality of life in older hospitalized patients.
results_summary: Mobility interventions showed a moderate improvement in physical activity (step count) and physical function, with no significant effect on length of stay and no increase in adverse events. The quality of evidence was low, indicating a need for more robust studies.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥60 years) admitted to general medicine units.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions mainly included ambulation and education).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of motor imagery (MI) on motor recovery and quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: Findings showed that pwMS using MI had significant improvements in walking speed and distance, fatigue, and quality of life, along with benefits in dynamic balance and perceived walking ability. Rehabilitation using MI with musical and verbal guides produced benefits on gait, fatigue, and QOL in pwMS with low disability scores.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) with low scores on the Expanded Disability Status Scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of flat flexible shoes versus stable supportive shoes on knee osteoarthritis symptoms, specifically walking pain and physical function.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that flat flexible shoes were superior to stable supportive shoes for improving walking pain or physical function. Contrary to the hypothesis, stable supportive shoes showed a greater improvement in knee pain compared to flat flexible shoes.
population_specificity: 164 patients with moderate to severe symptomatic radiographic medial knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (shoe types compared, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of bosentan combined with vardenafil in treating postoperative pulmonary hypertension in children with congenital heart disease, including assessing walking capacity via the 6-minute walking test.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking outcomes; it only mentions that the 6-minute walking test distance (6 MWTD) was an observation indicator.
population_specificity: Children with congenital heart disease and postoperative pulmonary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between exercise capacity (measured by walking distance) and endothelial function in patients with severe acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD).
results_summary: The study found a significant positive correlation between walking distance (6MWD) and endothelial function (FMD), with Pearson correlation coefficients of 0.36 (p=0.02) for FMD in mm and 0.40 (p=0.01) for FMD in %. Linear regression showed that 6MWD accounted for 15% of FMD variance.
population_specificity: 45 COPD patients diagnosed with severe AECOPD admitted to the University Hospital of São Carlos from 2017 to 2019.

study_goal: The study does not investigate Walking; it focuses on expiratory muscle training (EMT) for improving cough function and respiratory outcomes in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients.
results_summary: The study found that EMT improved peak cough flow, respiratory muscle function, and certain quality-of-life domains in CF patients, but it did not examine Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis (n=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise training (including walking) combined with compression therapy is more effective and safe for treating venous insufficiency compared to compression therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training (including walking) combined with compression therapy significantly improved most measured parameters (quality of life, clinical severity, walking tests, etc.) except hemodynamic status and edema, compared to compression therapy alone.
population_specificity: 24 patients with venous insufficiency.
effective_dosage: 2 days/week of supervised aerobic, strengthening, and stretching exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi versus walking and a waiting-list control on blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for walking; it outlines the study design and planned outcomes but does not report findings.
population_specificity: 234 hypertensive patients with mild to moderate essential hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different whole body vibration (WBV) frequencies on leg muscle strength, bone turnover, and walking endurance in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Both WBV protocols (20 Hz and 30 Hz) improved leg muscle strength and reduced bone resorption, with the 30 Hz protocol showing comparatively greater improvement in paretic eccentric leg strength. However, no significant effect was observed for walking endurance (6MWT).
population_specificity: Eighty-four individuals with chronic stroke (mean age 59.7 years) and mild to moderate motor impairment.
effective_dosage: 3 training sessions per week at either 20 Hz or 30 Hz WBV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait adaptability training on the C-Mill treadmill improves walking ability in people with pure hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP) compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study will assess the effects of C-Mill training on gait adaptability, balance, walking capacity, physical activity, and fall incidence in people with pure HSP, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with pure hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of 1-hour C-Mill training (twice per week).
study_duration: 5 weeks of intervention (weeks 17-21 for the initial group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) causing multiple skeletal destructions and walking difficulty in a young woman.
results_summary: The study found that PHPT caused severe skeletal destruction and walking difficulty in the patient, which significantly improved after parathyroidectomy and a 5-year follow-up.
population_specificity: A 30-year-old woman with PHPT and walking difficulty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of systematic early mobilization (including walking) in improving muscle strength and physical function in mechanically ventilated ICU patients.
results_summary: Systematic early mobilization showed benefits in SF-36 physical function and health scores, proportion of patients reaching independence, and time needed to walk compared to late mobilization, but no significant benefits for ICU-acquired weakness or muscle strength. Effects were stronger when compared to late mobilization than standard early mobilization, though evidence certainty was low.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated intensive care unit (ICU) patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention initiated within 7 days after ICU admission).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of inspiratory muscle training on inspiratory muscle function, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with asthma.
results_summary: The study found that 8 weeks of inspiratory muscle training significantly increased inspiratory muscle strength and endurance in patients with controlled asthma, with improvements in maximal inspiratory pressure and endurance test duration.
population_specificity: Patients with asthma, aged 20-70 years old, non-smokers.
effective_dosage: Six sets of 30 breaths per day, 5 days a week, with a training load ≥50% of maximal inspiratory pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured in-home walking program maintained mobility and improved outcomes in peripheral artery disease (PAD) patients during COVID-19 lockdowns.
results_summary: The study found that the walking program was adhered to safely, with improved pain-free walking distance (PFWD) and stable 6-minute walking distance (6MWD). New-entry subjects showed significant improvements in both measures, while previously enrolled subjects maintained stability, alongside decreased body weight and stable blood pressure and ankle-brachial index.
population_specificity: 83 PAD patients (age 72 ± 11, 65 males) enrolled in a walking program before COVID-19 lockdown.
effective_dosage: Two daily 8-minute sessions of slow intermittent in-home walking.
study_duration: 9 months pre-lockdown, with follow-up measurements 117 ± 23 days post-lockdown.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of prolonged sitting, prolonged standing, and sitting interrupted with regular walking breaks on vascular function and postprandial glucose metabolism.
results_summary: Regular walking breaks increased blood flow and shear stress, improved postprandial insulin response, and showed sustained benefits over 6 hours compared to prolonged sitting or standing. No significant effects were observed on glucose metabolism.
population_specificity: 18 normal-weight adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between physical activity time (≥150 min/week) and physical function in outpatients with type 2 diabetes who may have diabetic neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that patients who performed ≥150 min of physical activity per week had significantly higher isometric knee extensor strength, faster maximum 10-m walking speed, and better sit-to-stand time compared to those with <150 min of activity. A positive correlation was also observed between physical activity time and knee extensor strength.
population_specificity: Outpatients with type 2 diabetes who may have diabetic neuropathy (n=79).
effective_dosage: ≥150 minutes of physical activity per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of motor-cognitive dual-task training (mCdtt) and motor-motor dual-task training (mMdtt) on balance, fear of falling, walking functionality, and muscle strength in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that both mCdtt and mMdtt improved balance ability in older adults, but there was no significant difference between the two training methods in terms of balance, fear of falling, walking functionality, or muscle strength.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60 and over with a Mini-Mental State Exam score ≥ 24, Functional Ambulation Category ≥ 4, and no visual or hearing impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aerobic walking (AW) and exercise intensity on cognitive function in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found no significant overall cognitive improvement from AW but noted marginally significant benefits in verbal fluency and a significant group effect on attention and processing speed. Supervised moderate-intensity AW may offer potential cognitive benefits for schizophrenia patients.
population_specificity: 79 patients with schizophrenia (67 completed the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore gross motor abilities, particularly floor mobility (including walking and kneeling), in children with cerebral palsy (CP) to understand their choice of mobility.
results_summary: The study found that children with higher GMFCS levels (I and II) performed significantly better in walking and standing tasks compared to those at levels III and IV. Muscle strength in plantarflexors was higher in GMFCS level I than level II, but overall, differences in postural behavior may be linked to sensorimotor disturbances rather than muscle strength alone.
population_specificity: Thirty-six children with bilateral CP, median age 11.2 years, classified at GMFCS levels I-IV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a walking program integrated into cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic pain, comparing in-person and remote delivery methods.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in daily steps from baseline to treatment termination, with no significant difference between in-person and remote delivery. Adverse events were mostly minor and temporary, indicating the program was safe and effective in both formats.
population_specificity: Primarily male (72%), white (80%) participants with chronic pain (median duration: 11 years).
effective_dosage: Weekly goal to increase steps by 10% over the prior week's average.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and impact of a walking-based intervention on total sleep time (TST), sleep quality, and sleep disturbance in people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The walking intervention was feasible, safe, and highly acceptable, with participants in the exercise group showing significant improvements in sleep quality (Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index) compared to the control group. Recruitment and retention rates were moderate, and adherence to the intervention was high.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis (100% female, mean age 57 years).
effective_dosage: 28 sessions spread over 8 weeks (2-5 times/week), with 1 supervised session per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effectiveness of combination therapy (endovascular revascularization plus supervised exercise) versus supervised exercise alone for treating intermittent claudication.
results_summary: At 5-year follow-up, there was no significant difference in maximum walking distance or quality of life between the two treatment groups. However, supervised exercise alone was associated with a higher hazard of requiring additional revascularization procedures compared to combination therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tubular bandage, walking boot, and short leg plaster cast in treating avulsion fractures of the fifth metatarsal base.
results_summary: The study found marginal benefit of a walking boot over a short plaster cast during recovery but no difference in final outcomes. No evidence was available comparing tubular bandage and walking boot.
population_specificity: Patients with avulsion fractures of the base of the fifth metatarsal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare self-reported physical activity (via IPAQ) to Fitbit-measured step counts and determine which was a stronger predictor of BMI.
results_summary: Fitbit-measured physical activity was more strongly associated with BMI than self-reported activity, particularly for moderate and vigorous activity. Correlations between Fitbit and IPAQ measurements ranged from weak to moderate (0.09-0.48).
population_specificity: Adults enrolled in the Health eHeart Study who linked Fitbit data and completed an IPAQ (N=1498, subset n=586 for BMI analysis).
study_duration: Data collected between 2013 and 2019 (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the effectiveness of exercise training, including walking, for improving health outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise training, including walking, improved peak oxygen uptake (VO₂), walking performance, and self-reported quality of life (QoL) in PH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of BCI-FES on postural control and gait performance in individuals with chronic hemiparetic stroke.
results_summary: BCI-FES training significantly improved gait velocity, cadence, and step length compared to FES alone, demonstrating potential advantages for walking abilities in chronic hemiparetic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic hemiparetic stroke (25 participants, 13 in BCI-FES group, 12 in FES group).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 3 times per week for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuroanatomy and pathophysiology of gait initiation in Parkinson's disease, focusing on freezing of gait (FoG), and discuss potential targets for central nervous system neuromodulation.
results_summary: The study found that FoG is a heterogeneous phenomenon without a single unifying pathologic target, and future studies are needed to define effective therapeutic treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease experiencing freezing of gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare pediatric case of internal carotid artery dissection (ICAD) due to blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) and highlight diagnostic challenges.
results_summary: The study found that the patient with ICAD had no specific neurological symptoms and was discharged walking without support after 55 days, suggesting recovery despite the silent nature of the condition.
population_specificity: A 14-year-old boy with major trauma from a motor vehicle accident.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in health-related quality of life (HRQoL) over time in SSc patients and assess how different SSc domains and functional impairments, including walking (measured by six-minute walking distance), contribute to these changes.
results_summary: The study found that worse functioning, as measured by six-minute walking distance, was significantly associated with deterioration of HRQoL over time in SSc patients. Other factors like gastrointestinal symptoms, Raynaud, digital ulcers, and pulmonary arterial hypertension also contributed to worsening HRQoL.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc), including incident (disease duration <24 months) and prevalent cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and determinants of concern about falling (CF) in older people with vision impairment due to age-related macular degeneration (AMD) compared to visually normal controls.
results_summary: The study found that older people with AMD had higher concern about falling scores compared to controls, though this difference was not significant after adjusting for age. In the AMD group, greater CF was associated with reduced contrast sensitivity, slower sit-to-stand times, and higher anxiety scores.
population_specificity: Older people (mean age 80.5 ± 6.2 years for AMD group, 75.4 ± 5.3 years for controls) with and without vision impairment due to AMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of neuromuscular versus classical strength-resistance training in improving cardiorespiratory fitness, lower-limb performance, and quality of life in cardiac rehabilitation patients.
results_summary: The study will evaluate the mean difference in change from baseline in the Incremental Shuttle Walking Test, cardiorespiratory fitness, lower-limb performance, strength, sexual dysfunction, and quality of life, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with acute coronary syndrome recruited from a private tertiary hospital.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions divided into aerobic training and neuromuscular or classical strength-resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between daily steps, gait speed, and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk, particularly in stroke survivors, and to assess the potential benefits of rehabilitation interventions like high-intensity gait training.
results_summary: The study found that increasing daily steps, even to 5000, is associated with reduced CVD risk, but many adults and CVD patients walk fewer steps. Reduced gait speed, linked to biomechanical changes and CVD, is particularly noticeable post-stroke. Current interventions like high-intensity gait training show promise but require more research to determine optimal dosages and methods.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly those with cardiovascular disease and stroke survivors.

study_goal: To assess the effect of home-based over-ground robotic-assisted gait training on clinical functional outcomes in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking distance (Six-Minute Walk Test) and other functional outcomes (e.g., Timed-Up-and-Go, Dynamic Gait Index) with robotic-assisted gait training, which were maintained at 22 weeks. Physical activity also increased compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory chronic stroke patients receiving usual physiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 10-week over-ground robotic-assisted gait training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical presentation, diagnostic challenges, and progression of spinal muscular atrophy type 3 (SMA3) and type 4 (SMA4), focusing on motor function and ambulation.
results_summary: The study found that SMA3 patients typically lose ambulation over time despite initially achieving independent walking, while SMA4 patients remain ambulatory until at least the fifth decade. Molecular genetic testing is crucial for diagnosis, as clinical presentation can mimic muscular dystrophy.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal muscular atrophy type 3 (SMA3) and type 4 (SMA4).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and use of therapeutic erythrocytapheresis (TEA) in treating chronic mountain sickness (CMS), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that TEA significantly improved oxygen saturation, reduced erythrocytosis, and improved clinical scores (CMS, Borg dyspnea, NYHA classification, and 6-min walking test) in CMS patients. The procedure was well tolerated with no complications.
population_specificity: 32 patients with chronic mountain sickness living in the Shigatse area of Tibet (altitude 4000 m).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify additional risk factors for neuromuscular hip dysplasia (NHD) in teenagers with cerebral palsy, including the role of poor walking abilities.
results_summary: The study found that 27% of teenagers with cerebral palsy had NHD, with poor walking abilities identified as a risk factor by the logistic regression model.
population_specificity: 102 teenagers with cerebral palsy (60 males, 42 females; mean age 16.5 ± 1.2 years).
study_duration: Data collected between 2007 and 2017 (cross-sectional study, no specific intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of employer-based walking challenges as an intervention to increase physical activity in Mexican-Americans.
results_summary: The study found that walking challenges involving over 2000 participants and several employers were feasible and suggested potential for increasing physical activity in Mexican-Americans.
population_specificity: Predominantly Mexican-American community in El Paso, Texas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether insoles with a toe-grip bar reduce occupational leg swelling and increase lower limb muscle activity in individuals who sit or stand for prolonged periods.
results_summary: The study found that insoles with a toe-grip bar significantly reduced leg swelling and increased muscle activity in the tibialis anterior and gastrocnemius muscles during walking compared to regular insoles.
population_specificity: 12 healthy men who work in sitting or standing positions.
effective_dosage: Wearing insoles with a toe-grip bar for 8 hours per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the subjective, clinical, and biomechanical outcomes of medial pivot (MP) and posterior stabilized (PS) total knee arthroplasty (TKA) designs in patients undergoing walking assessments.
results_summary: The MP TKA group showed significantly better subjective outcomes (higher Forgotten Joint Score) compared to the PS TKA group, but no significant differences were found in clinical (range of motion) or functional (gait analysis) outcomes between the two designs.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA) in a single-center, single-surgeon setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of rhythm-based music therapy on gait and walking ability in ischemic stroke patients and evaluate its value in walking training.
results_summary: The study found that music therapy improved stride length, cadence, maximum velocity, balance (BBS scores), lower limb motor function (FMA scores), and treatment satisfaction compared to conventional therapy alone. These improvements were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Sixty ischemic stroke patients admitted to a hospital between October 2017 and December 2018.
effective_dosage: Music therapy was administered daily (except Sundays) for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functional improvements in motor activities, including walking, in patients with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) through multidisciplinary management and innovative therapies.
results_summary: The study highlights that innovative therapies and multidisciplinary approaches can modify the natural history of SMA, potentially improving motor function, but emphasizes the need for balanced consideration of child development and disease progression. Walking is one of the activities assessed, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for walking alone.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA types 1, 2, and 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and quantify risk factors associated with falls in elderly patients after total joint arthroplasty (TJA).
results_summary: The study found a 13.1% accumulated incidence of falls post-TJA, with key risk factors including advanced age, female sex, overweight, falls history, use of walking aids, and comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension. The ABC Scale was negatively correlated with falls after lower extremity joint replacement.
population_specificity: Elderly patients who underwent total joint arthroplasty (TJA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combining virtual reality (VR) and motor imagery (MI) with routine physical therapy, including walking and cycling, on motor function, balance, and activities of daily living in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study compared routine physical therapy alone (Group A) to routine therapy combined with VR and MI (Group B). While specific results are not detailed in the abstract, the study measured outcomes using standardized scales (UPDRS, BBS, ABC) at multiple time points, suggesting a structured evaluation of walking and cycling interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (Modified Hoehn and Yahr stages I-III).
effective_dosage: Group A: 20 min of walking and cycling per session, 3 days per week. Group B: Routine physical therapy plus VR and MI in 60-min sessions, 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of early Computerized Balance Training on balance, walking endurance, and independence in activities of daily living for persons with mild hemiparesis in the subacute phase of stroke.
results_summary: The study found that Computerized Balance Training significantly improved balance (Berg Balance Scale, Tinetti Balance Scale), sensory integration, and walking endurance (Two Minutes Walk Test) compared to conventional physiotherapy alone. The experimental group showed statistically significant improvements in multiple outcome measures.
population_specificity: Persons with mild hemiparesis in the subacute phase of stroke (within 4 weeks from onset), able to maintain a standing position for at least 30 seconds.
effective_dosage: Experimental group received conventional physiotherapy (40 minutes once daily) plus Computerized Balance Training (once daily), 5 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of total hip arthroplasty (THA) and hemiarthroplasty (HA) in active patients aged ≥80 years with displaced femoral neck fractures.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking outcomes, as the study is still ongoing and aims to assess differences in Harris hip score (HHS) and walking distance at follow-up intervals.
population_specificity: Active patients aged ≥80 years with displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures, excluding those with advanced osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
study_duration: Follow-up evaluations at 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, and 3 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pharmacological treatments that increase dystrophin synthesis in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) on functional outcomes, including walking distance and other measures.
results_summary: Eteplirsen showed significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) at 48 weeks and 3 years, while Ataluren and Drisapersen had modest but significant effects in meta-analysis. All drugs induced partial dystrophin synthesis, with Eteplirsen also improving respiratory function.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate reconstruction techniques for the abductor mechanism (AM) of the hip after tumor resection and their impact on functional outcomes, including walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that reconstruction techniques for the AM, such as allograft prosthesis composites or modular megaprostheses, yield nearly identical long-term functional outcomes, though each has specific complications. Functional outcomes are generally good unless a complete musculotendinous unit or the superior gluteal nerve is sacrificed.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing tumor resection in the hip area with compromised abductor mechanism function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-magnitude high-frequency vibration (LMHFV) on vertebral bone mineral density, muscle health, balancing ability, and functional outcomes in wheelchair-using elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results regarding Walking, as it focused on LMHFV therapy for wheelchair users. The abstract indicates the study is ongoing, with outcomes to be assessed at 6 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65 or above with walking difficulties who primarily use wheelchairs for outdoor activities.
effective_dosage: LMHFV (35 Hz, 0.3g, 20 min/day, at least three times/week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical and cognitive performance, neurophysiological, and MRI outcomes between responders and non-responders to Fampridine treatment in individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and examine associations with disability and walking impairment scales.
results_summary: The study found no differences in physical, cognitive, neurophysiological, or MRI outcomes between Fampridine responders and non-responders. Central motor conduction time (CMCT) was associated with walking impairment and disability, while cognitive performance (SDMT) was linked to white matter lesions on MRI.
population_specificity: Individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) classified as responders or non-responders to Fampridine treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how overground robotic (OR) training added to ongoing rehabilitation affects gait speed, lower extremity function, functional mobility, and fatigue in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and moderate to severe gait impairments.
results_summary: The OR group maintained gait speed and significantly improved functional mobility without increasing fatigue, while the control group showed a decline in gait speed and reduced fatigue. No significant interactions between time and group were observed for any variable.
population_specificity: Individuals with MS (N=36), aged 18 or older, with Expanded Disability Status Scale scores between 4.5 and 7, requiring assistive devices for walking outdoors.
effective_dosage: Twice-weekly individualized and progressive OR gait training, aiming for up to 40 minutes per session by the end of 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to categorize aspects of the motor skill of walking and evaluate how trunk-acceleration gait measures can assess gait quality and predict motor skill decline in older adults.
results_summary: The study suggests that gait measures from accelerometers can enrich walking and motor performance assessments, providing more detailed information than simple gait measurements like speed. It highlights the potential of complex acceleration measures to predict motor skill decline and improve fall research in older adults.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining continuous exercise with intermittent breaks in prolonged sitting on postprandial glucose, insulin, and triglyceride metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that combining exercise with breaks in sitting reduced postprandial insulin and insulin-glucose ratios more effectively than uninterrupted sitting, with additional reductions in triglycerides. However, individuals with high fasting triglycerides showed no significant reduction in triglyceride levels.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults who were overweight to obese (mean age 67 years, BMI 31.2 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of pharmacological osteoporosis prevention (including vitamin D, calcium, and bisphosphonates) in nursing home residents and its association with patient characteristics such as falls, fractures, cognitive impairment, and dependence in walking.
results_summary: The study found low usage of osteoporosis medications (OMs) among nursing home residents, with only 1.5% using all three classes (vitamin D, calcium, and bisphosphonates). Usage varied widely by country, and under-treatment was noted in residents with recent falls, fractures, or walking dependence, while possible over-treatment occurred in those with high mortality risk.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents from eight countries (Czech Republic, England, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, The Netherlands, and Israel).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BMI influences the effects of acute physical activity (treadmill walking) on inhibitory control task performance in children.
results_summary: Children showed improved task performance and decreased interference after walking compared to restful reading, with greater benefits for tasks requiring higher inhibitory control. Higher BMI was associated with reduced performance benefits following acute exercise.
population_specificity: 116 children aged 8-11 (51 females) pooled from four prior studies.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of treadmill walking at 60-70% heart rate max.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether contoured foot orthoses reduce first MTP joint pain on walking compared to sham flat insoles in people with first MTP joint OA.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so final results are not yet available. It will compare pain reduction and other symptoms between contoured foot orthoses and sham insoles over 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling people with symptomatic radiographic first MTP joint OA (n=88).
effective_dosage: Daily use of allocated insoles when wearing shoes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of inspiratory muscle training and aerobic exercise (including walking) versus standard care on postoperative outcomes in lung cancer patients undergoing VATS.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in respiratory muscle strength (PImax) and aerobic capacity (6MWT) as early as 2 weeks postoperatively, with sustained benefits at 6 and 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients who underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (aerobic exercise component included walking, but exact dosage/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of omega-3 fatty acids on sarcopenia-related performances, including muscle mass and walking speed, in the elderly.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found minor benefits for muscle mass gain and timed up-and-go performance, with greater improvements observed at dosages above 2 g/day and interventions lasting more than 6 months. Walking speed improved significantly with long-term omega-3 supplementation.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between ocular discomfort severity and quality of life, including interference with activities like walking, in patients with moderate to severe dry eye disease.
results_summary: The study found that worse ocular discomfort correlated moderately to strongly with interference in daily activities, including walking ability, but did not specifically evaluate walking as an intervention or outcome.
population_specificity: Patients (N = 535) with moderate to severe dry eye disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Cureit™ supplementation in managing sarcopenia by measuring variables such as walking endurance and general fitness parameters.
results_summary: The study found that Cureit supplementation led to a significant 1.43% improvement in measured variables, including walking endurance, though the full extent of results is not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with sarcopenial conditions, likely older adults given the context of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how microplanning could optimize community health workers' walking routes and time investment to improve Seasonal Malaria Chemoprevention (SMC) coverage.
results_summary: Microplanning reduced walking distance by 25%, increased household visits by 36%, and boosted SMC coverage by 21%, with optimal itineraries achieving 100% coverage in small villages. Larger villages required additional CHW ratio optimization.
population_specificity: Children in Sub-Saharan African villages with varying demographics and geographies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether AI-assisted markerless motion capture (OpenPose) is useful for assessing gait in clinical and rehabilitation settings, particularly for individuals with lower limb dysfunction.
results_summary: OpenPose showed strong correlation with conventional passive marker motion capture and manual video analysis for hip and knee joint angles, though weaker for ankle joints. It was deemed an adequate substitute for assessing both normal and abnormal gait, including cases involving orthoses or crutches.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb dysfunction, including those using ankle foot orthoses or crutches, and impaired metatarsophalangeal joint motion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore a measure of the temporal dimension of poststroke recovery, identify predictive associations with clinical variables, and improve tailoring of poststroke treatments, focusing on motor milestones like autonomous walking.
results_summary: The study found that patients showed significant improvement in Fugl-Meyer and FIM scores during rehabilitation, with autonomous walking milestone acquisition linked to initial Fugl-Meyer scores and length of stay. The Fugl-Meyer score was a valuable predictor for milestone reacquisition.
population_specificity: 176 poststroke inpatients at their first cerebrovascular event.
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on milestone reacquisition times, averaging less than 30 days when attainable).

study_goal: The researchers were examining cases of internal fixation failures after periprosthetic femoral fractures in a patient with low bone mass and overweight status.
results_summary: The study reported three failures of internal fixation in a patient with low bone mass (T-score -1.7) and a high BMI (28.7 kg/m²). No direct findings on Walking were mentioned.
population_specificity: A patient with low bone mass and overweight status who experienced periprosthetic femoral fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability, responsiveness, and convergent validity of the Four-Meter Walk Test (4mWT) compared to the Six-Minute Walk Test (6MWT) in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The 4mWT (fastest) showed excellent test-retest reliability, small measurement error, and high responsiveness in the postoperative period, with strong convergent validity to the 6MWT. The study suggests the 4mWT may be preferred for clinical assessment due to its practicality.
population_specificity: 162 patients (mean age 63.5 ± 7.4 years; 89 females) undergoing TKA.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted preoperatively (1-2 weeks) and postoperatively at 1, 2, 3, 6, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, recruitment barriers, and effects of TENS combined with aerobic exercise on functional capacity, cardiorespiratory fitness, and cardiovascular autonomic function in individuals with intermittent claudication (Fontaine stage II).
results_summary: The study found low recruitment and adherence rates, with only 12.6% of screened participants included. The most efficient recruitment sources were physician and physiotherapist referrals, but overall, the trial highlighted challenges in managing peripheral arterial disease (PAD) care.
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (Fontaine stage II) residing in Brazil.
effective_dosage: Experimental group received 45 minutes of TENS (10 Hz) followed by 30 minutes of aerobic exercise; control group received placebo TENS followed by 30 minutes of exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a fall-inducing movable platform (FIMP) to simulate ecologically valid falls in a controlled laboratory setting for studying fall mechanisms and recovery strategies.
results_summary: The FIMP successfully induced trips and slips, with subjects exhibiting characteristic reactive strategies (e.g., leg lowering, skipping, and surfing). Statistical analysis confirmed the platform's ability to replicate real-world fall kinematics.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied healthy subjects in a laboratory setting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the immediate benefits of genicular nerve blockade on pain, gait, and stair kinematics in patients with knee osteoarthritis in Cameroon.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain and perceived difficulty, along with improvements in cadence, hip sagittal range of motion during gait, and angular speed range during stair descent.
population_specificity: 14 women with painful knee osteoarthritis (grade 2-4) in Cameroon.
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed 1 hour after injection.

study_goal: To investigate the feasibility and acceptability of a home-based exercise program monitored using telehealth for people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found high adherence rates (93% in Block 1, 84-93% in Block 2) and reported that participants found the exercise helpful and could follow the home program. However, there was no significant difference between groups in secondary outcomes like balance, gait speed, and freezing of gait.
population_specificity: Forty people with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease, mean age 72 (6.9).
study_duration: Block 1: 5 weeks; Block 2: duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to debunk common myths about pediatric orthopedic conditions related to walking (e.g., flexible flatfeet, in-toeing/out-toeing, W-sitting, toe-walking) and provide evidence-based recommendations on diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that flexible flatfeet, in-toeing/out-toeing, W-sitting, and toe-walking typically improve without intervention, and treatments like orthotics, bracing, or physical therapy lack scientific support. Misinformation about these conditions is widespread, but most cases resolve naturally during childhood.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with common orthopedic findings (e.g., flexible flatfeet, in-toeing/out-toeing, W-sitting, toe-walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of non-invasive ventilation (NIV) during exercise training on exercise capacity, quality of life, functional performance, and symptoms in individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: NIV during exercise training improved exercise performance (6-minute walking distance), quality of life, dyspnea, oxygen saturation, PaO2, PaCO2, blood lactate levels, and breath rate in COPD individuals compared to exercise alone. No significant differences were found in exercise duration, BODE index, minute ventilation, heart rate, or systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of DHS and PFNA surgeries on elderly osteoporosis patients, including their impact on BALP expression and postoperative recovery.
results_summary: PFNA surgery resulted in shorter operation time, less blood loss, faster recovery, fewer complications, and better functional outcomes (e.g., walking speed) compared to DHS. PFNA also led to lower BALP expression levels postoperatively.
population_specificity: 116 elderly patients with osteoporotic fractures.
study_duration: Postoperative measurements were taken 30 days after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between walking and mental health and wellbeing in people with rheumatoid arthritis during COVID-19 lockdown, and examine the moderation effects of self-isolating.
results_summary: Walking was negatively associated with physical fatigue and depressive symptoms and positively associated with vitality. The study also found that walking was related to lower physical fatigue in people who were self-isolating.
population_specificity: 345 rheumatoid arthritis patients during the United Kingdom COVID-19 lockdown.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) versus primary stenting (PS) for treating stenotic and occlusive lesions of the iliac artery.
results_summary: The study found no conclusive evidence to favor PTA with selective stenting over primary stenting for iliac artery lesions, though primary stenting may reduce distal embolisation rates in occlusions. The evidence was of low certainty due to limitations in risk of bias, imprecision, and indirectness.
population_specificity: Patients with iliac artery occlusive disease (stenotic or occlusive lesions).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 12 months to eight years across studies.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the optimal administration method, safety, and clinical efficacy of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) transplantation in patients with progressive multiple sclerosis, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that MSC transplantation, particularly intrathecal administration, reduced treatment failure rates and disease activity compared to sham treatment, with additional benefits on relapse rate and functional tests. No serious safety issues were reported.
population_specificity: 48 patients (28 males, 20 females) with progressive multiple sclerosis (EDSS 3.0-6.5, mean age 47.5 ± 12.3).
study_duration: 14 months (with retreatment at 6 months for some groups).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects and acceptability of an individualized semi-supervised home-based exercise program on functional mobility, balance, and lower limb strength in men with myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and to assess the impact of an assistive training device.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in most outcome measures except for knee flexor strength. All participants improved beyond the standard error of measurement in at least two outcomes, and the program and device were well accepted with perceived improvements reported.
population_specificity: Men with the adult form of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1).
effective_dosage: Three exercises (sit-to-stand, squat, and alternated lunges) performed three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a home-based rehabilitation program versus traditional outpatient physiotherapy for improving functional outcomes in high-risk patients after knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no clinically or statistically significant differences in functional outcomes between the home-based rehabilitation and usual-care groups at 12 months, though the home-based intervention was more cost-effective due to reduced time away from work.
population_specificity: People identified as being at high risk of a poor outcome after knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Home-based group received a median of 5 sessions (IQR 4-7); usual-care group received a median of 4 sessions (IQR 2-6).
study_duration: 12 months (primary outcome measured at this time).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of intraarterial autologous bone marrow-derived stem cell (BMSC) injection for treating severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that intraarterial BMSC injection significantly improved ankle-brachial index (ABI) and transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2) compared to sham injection, with no reported complications.
population_specificity: 81 patients with severe PAD (77 men), including 56 with critical limb ischemia and 25 with severe claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion of COPD patients completing pulmonary rehabilitation who met NICE criteria for a respiratory review to assess eligibility for lung volume reduction therapies.
results_summary: Between 4.9% and 18.1% of pulmonary rehabilitation completers met the NICE criteria for a respiratory review, depending on the thresholds used for walking test performance and dyspnea scores. The study highlights the need for clearer treatment pathways to ensure equitable access to effective therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who completed pulmonary rehabilitation programs in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether regular physical activity, including walking, could strengthen the immune system in older adults and reduce the risk of COVID-19 infection.
results_summary: The study found that older adults can maintain activity and health during the COVID-19 pandemic through walking and other exercises, which may positively impact their immune system. Walking, along with other activities, was suggested as a beneficial practice for immune support in this population.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the test-retest reliability, agreement, and convergent validity of the Lean-and-Release test for assessing reactive stepping in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury or disease (iSCI/D).
results_summary: The Lean-and-Release test demonstrated reliable behavioral responses (ICC = 0.76) and correlated with lower extremity strength (0.54) and balance confidence (0.55). Swing time of reactive stepping also correlated with over-ground walking parameters (step time: 0.73; cadence: -0.73).
population_specificity: Individuals with motor incomplete spinal cord injury or disease (iSCI/D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a care intervention program, including walking and other physical activities, on pregnancy outcomes in women with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The intervention program, which included walking, significantly improved maternal pregnancy outcomes such as gestational diabetes and weight gain, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 120 singleton pregnant women with metabolic syndrome from two health centers in Babol.
effective_dosage: Walking activities were included in three training sessions, but specific dosage (e.g., duration, frequency) was not detailed.
study_duration: The intervention duration was not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: To determine if adding core stability exercises to usual care physiotherapy improves patient outcomes after stroke.
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence that core stability exercises added to usual care physiotherapy improved trunk control and dynamic balance in stroke patients.
population_specificity: People with stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different types of exercise, including walking, in reducing falls among older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the effects of walking on reducing falls remain uncertain, unlike other exercises such as balance and functional exercises, which showed significant reductions in fall rates.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60+ years living in the community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a rehabilitation program involving isometric quadriceps exercise with auditory and visual feedback on short-term outcomes after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study assessed the impact of a structured rehabilitation program on post-TKA recovery, though specific results regarding Walking were not detailed in the provided abstract. The intervention group's outcomes were compared to a control group, but exact findings were not summarized.
population_specificity: 62 patients planning a primary unilateral TKA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Otago exercises versus walking on falls, balance, and physical performance in elderly nursing home residents at high risk of falls.
results_summary: The walking group showed no significant improvement in falls reduction or balance compared to the Otago group, but maintained baseline physical performance (6MWT distance) without decline. Walking alone did not significantly enhance secondary outcomes like balance or chair stand performance.
population_specificity: Elderly adults over 65 years with high fall risk, residing in a nursing home in Izmir, Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if objective smartphone measurements of physical activity (steps/day) and fitness (6-minute walking distance) could predict early discontinuation in cancer patients participating in early-phase clinical trials.
