results_summary: Lower physical activity (<900 steps/day) and fitness (<285 m in 6 minutes) were significantly associated with higher odds of early trial discontinuation. Patients who walked both <1500 steps/day and <300 m in 6 minutes had a 100% positive predictive value for early discontinuation.
population_specificity: Cancer patients participating in early-phase clinical trials.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (measured steps/day and 6-minute walking distance).
study_duration: Measured before treatment start; follow-up until discontinuation or beyond 28 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between self-reported physical activity (including walking) and menopausal symptoms, and whether a digitally-delivered lifestyle intervention could improve these outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in time spent walking between intervention and control groups, and walking was not independently associated with changes in menopausal symptoms. Moderate and vigorous physical activity showed a stepwise association with lower menopausal symptom scores, but walking did not.
population_specificity: Women previously treated for early-stage breast, reproductive, and blood cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an ICF Core Set to assess the functioning and health of community-dwelling geriatric patients aged 75 and older in primary care.
results_summary: The study identified common impairments in body functions and activities for older adults but did not specifically address walking's effects.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 75 and older in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of commonly used drugs (beraprost, clopidogrel, aspirin, sarpogrelate, cilostazol) on intermittent claudication in patients with peripheral arterial diseases, focusing on walking distance and ankle-brachial index.
results_summary: Beraprost, sarpogrelate, and cilostazol showed better therapeutic effects for maximum walking distance, while beraprost, beraprost combined with aspirin, and sarpogrelate improved pain-free walking distance. Sarpogrelate, beraprost, and aspirin were associated with fewer severe adverse events compared to cilostazol and placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial diseases experiencing intermittent claudication (n=9491).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a specialized exercise training program as an add-on to medical therapy in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: The study found that the exercise training program significantly improved the 6-minute walking distance by 34.1 meters, enhanced quality of life, improved WHO-functional class, and increased peak oxygen consumption compared to the control group. The training was feasible, safe, and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with PAH (n=98) and CTEPH (n=18), mean age 53.6 years, 85 female, WHO functional class II (53%) and III (46%).
effective_dosage: Standardized in-hospital rehabilitation with mean duration of 25 days, continued at home.
study_duration: Mean 25 days in-hospital, continued at home (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interrupting prolonged sitting with activity breaks (including walking) had acute and chronic effects on postprandial lipid metabolism.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking's effects, only stating it is a secondary analysis of an experimental study.
population_specificity: 16 sedentary healthy adults (7 men, 24 ± 3 years, BMI 22.2 ± 2.3 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing (during or after treatment) for initiating a home-based adapted physical activity (APA) program to improve cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that home-based APA had a positive effect on CRF and physical functions in breast cancer patients, with no significant differences based on the timing of the program relative to cancer treatment. The majority of participants completed over 85% of the exercise sessions.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify primary predictors of walking function recovery in nonambulatory stroke patients undergoing high-intensity training during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that stepping activity, baseline Berg Balance Scale scores, and paretic leg strength were key predictors of walking recovery, with higher step counts correlating with unassisted walking at discharge. ROC analyses indicated that even low-functioning patients could achieve independent walking early poststroke.
population_specificity: Nonambulatory individuals less than 6 months poststroke requiring walking assistance at admission (N=257).
effective_dosage: Median of 1270 steps per day (interquartile range: 533-2297).
study_duration: Duration of inpatient rehabilitation (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of daily walking exercise on sleep quality, perceived stress, and life satisfaction, and investigate its interaction with sleep components.
results_summary: The study found that daily aerobic walking exercise improved sleep quality and reduced perceived stress, with no significant change in life satisfaction. The intervention group showed better outcomes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 54 research volunteers (intervention and control groups)
effective_dosage: Daily aerobic walking exercise (specific duration/intensity not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of high-dose biotin (MD1003) in improving disability and walking speed in patients with progressive multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that MD1003 did not significantly improve disability or walking speed compared to placebo, with similar rates of adverse events in both groups. One death occurred in the MD1003 group, and the treatment interfered with laboratory test accuracy.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 with primary or secondary progressive multiple sclerosis, minimal disability (EDSS 3.5-6.5), and no relapses in the past 2 years.
effective_dosage: 100 mg oral biotin three times daily.
interactions: Interference with laboratory tests using biotinylated antibodies.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a nursing intervention (Fall Prevention) in reducing falls in older adults with arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in self-reported falls compared to the control group, with fewer falls attributed to difficulty walking and other environmental/behavioral factors. The intervention was deemed effective in reducing fall occurrences.
population_specificity: Older adults with arterial hypertension from a city in Northeast Brazil.

study_goal: To investigate whether replacing canes with an elasticated orthotic-garment improves balance and gait-function in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in Functional-Gait-Assessment (FGA) scores and reduced trunk-sway in some participants when using the orthotic-garment, indicating better stability. However, results varied by participant during follow-up, with some maintaining improvements, others stabilizing, and one deteriorating.
population_specificity: Four chronic stroke survivors who previously used canes.
effective_dosage: Orthotic-garment worn throughout the day with maximal cane-use reduction.
study_duration: Phase A (9-12 weeks), Phase B (9-16 weeks), Phase C (9-10 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinically important difference (CID) for two measures of walking ability in mobility-limited older men.
results_summary: The study found that CID estimates for walking ability varied by method and population, with increases of 16-30 meters for 6MWD and 5-15 points for PF10 over 12 months being clinically meaningful in mobility-limited older hypogonadal men.
population_specificity: Mobility-limited older men with gait speed <1.2 m/second and self-reported mobility limitation (n = 429).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of external diaphragmatic pacing (EDP) on patients with chronic cor pulmonale (CCP), specifically assessing respiratory and walking performance.
results_summary: The study found that EDP treatment significantly improved maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP), forced vital capacity (FVC), and 6-minute walking test performance compared to standard anti-CCP therapy alone. These improvements were observed after ten days of treatment.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with chronic cor pulmonale (CCP) in Kashgar Prefecture, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a 12-month multifactorial intervention by primary care nurses could increase adherence to a physical activity prescription (150 min/week) in patients with two or more cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The intervention group showed higher adherence to the 150-min weekly physical activity recommendation compared to the control group. The approach was feasible in primary healthcare settings and could be implemented as a main tool for exercise prescription.
population_specificity: Patients with two or more cardiovascular risk factors from 20 primary healthcare centers in Mallorca.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of physical activity per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of elastic band resistance training on walking kinetics and muscle activities in young adults with genu valgus.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training with elastic bands significantly improved peak medial ground reaction force, time-to-peak for posterior ground reaction force, and muscle activities in the rectus femoris and gluteus medius during walking. The intervention group showed clinically meaningful improvements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Male young adults (mean age 22.5 years) with genu valgus.
effective_dosage: Not specified (14-week elastic band resistance training program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the agreement between behavioural mapping and accelerometry for measuring mobility levels (including walking) in acute medical inpatients and to evaluate the resources and costs of both methods.
results_summary: The study found good to excellent agreement between behavioural mapping and accelerometry for measuring 'lying', 'sitting', and 'upright' but poor agreement for 'standing' and 'walking'. Both methods were labour-intensive, with accelerometry requiring additional financial investment for equipment.
population_specificity: Adult patients admitted to two acute medical wards in a tertiary referral teaching hospital in Brisbane, Australia (mean age 72 years, 53% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of acupuncture on gait disturbance and cerebral hemodynamic changes in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Acupuncture treatment significantly reduced cadence and improved Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) scores related to walking and balance, suggesting it may help improve hypometric gait and cerebral cortex activation in PD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (n = 26) experiencing gait disturbance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a six-month individualized coaching program on walking capacity in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking distance performance between the intervention group (receiving coaching) and the control group (receiving standard care) at the end of the six-month program or at the six-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (first ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, within <6 months post-stroke, age ≥18 years).
effective_dosage: Monitored physical activity, home visits, and weekly phone calls (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of mechanically assisted walking training (with or without body weight support) compared to no walking training or the same dose of overground walking training on walking performance, participation, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Mechanically assisted walking training (with or without body weight support) showed small increases in walking speed and some improvements in gross motor function compared to no walking training. Compared to overground walking training, mechanically assisted walking without body weight support was more effective for walking speed and gross motor function, while training with body weight support showed little to no difference.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMFCS Levels I to IV), aged 3 to 18 years.
effective_dosage: Training sessions ranged from 15 to 40 minutes, 2 to 5 times per week.
study_duration: Intervention periods ranged from 4 to 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of density and number of sessions of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) on pain, fatigue, disability, physical function, and quality of life in patients with plantar fasciitis (PF).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: 94 patients diagnosed with plantar fasciitis (PF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing research on the effects of fear of falling (FOF) and therapy options in people with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: The study found that higher FOF scores in pwMS were associated with more frequent falls, lower walking speed, shorter stride length, larger sway area, and greater disability. Current therapeutic options focus on physiotherapy, with assisted vibration mentioned as a potential intervention.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an automated method to analyze accelerometer data for detecting home-based exercise sessions in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and assess its correlation with improvements in peak walking time.
results_summary: The algorithm successfully detected exercise sessions with 85% sensitivity and 90% specificity. Algorithm-detected exercise sessions and intensity were correlated with improvements in peak walking time after 6 months of training.
population_specificity: 54 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) enrolled in a clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an individualized assisted walking program (IAWP) could improve walking ability in hospitalized older patients compared to usual care.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly improved walking ability at discharge compared to the control group, with no statistically significant differences in adverse events. No adverse effects were detected.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients aged 65 and older.
study_duration: From hospital admission to discharge (study conducted between October 2018 and January 2020).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of thoracic paravertebral nerve block (TPVB) on early postoperative rehabilitation, including walking performance, in patients undergoing thoracoscopic lung cancer surgery.
results_summary: The TPVB group showed a lower decline rate in the 6-minute walking test (6MWT), longer walking distances, higher completion rates, reduced pain scores, lower oxycodone consumption, and better sleep quality compared to the general anesthesia group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective video-assisted thoracoscopic lobectomy for lung cancer (n=90).
study_duration: Assessed on postoperative days 1 and 2 (POD1, POD2).

study_goal: To determine if self-management exercise intervention, including walking, reduces postoperative cancer-related fatigue and improves self-management efficacy in non-small cell lung cancer patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significantly lower fatigue scores and higher self-efficacy scores for continuous walking and balance ability compared to the control group after six weeks. Physical and mental health scores also improved more in the experimental group.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer post-surgery (70 participants, 35 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and define specific aspects of social learning, including its neural and behavioral mechanisms, and explore its applications in fields like psychotherapy and medical sociology.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of social learning in humans and rodents, its role in modifying memories and buffering stress, and introduces new findings on the social modulation of learning, including the concept of "social engrams" and potential therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Humans and rodents (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic effectiveness of the quadratus lumborum block type 3 (QLB3) versus the posterior lumbar plexus block (LPB) for pain management after primary hip replacement surgery.
results_summary: The QLB3 provided non-inferior analgesia compared to LPB, with no significant differences in opioid consumption or walking recovery time, but fewer cases of quadriceps weakness. Block performance time was significantly shorter with QLB3.
population_specificity: 46 patients undergoing primary hip replacement surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (block techniques compared, not dosages).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed up to 24 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-cost devices (Wii Balance Board and Kinect v2) in objectively assessing posture and gait in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients compared to conventional clinical scales.
results_summary: The study found that low-cost devices effectively detected posture and gait impairments in PD, particularly in H&Y stage II.5 and akinetic/rigid phenotypes. Dual-task gait evaluation was more sensitive in distinguishing PD stages and controls than free gait.
population_specificity: 54 individuals with Parkinson's disease and 43 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (assessment study, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of total hip arthroplasty for treating Crowe type IV DDH combined with an intertrochanteric fracture, including postoperative walking outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that total hip arthroplasty with subtrochanteric shortening osteotomy and fracture fixation led to significant improvements in pain (VAS) and function (mHSS scores), with the patient resuming walking with support at 3 days post-surgery and achieving near-full range of motion by 6 months.
population_specificity: A 75-year-old patient with Crowe type IV DDH and an intertrochanteric fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercising together influences exercise adherence and cardiometabolic risk in African-American romantic couples.
results_summary: Trends suggested that exercising together may promote walking adherence, with the exercising-together group walking more minutes per week than the exercising-separately group. The intervention also showed significant improvements in several cardiometabolic risk factors, including waist circumference, body fat, and HDL levels.
population_specificity: African-American romantic couples (average age 62.8 years, BMI 31.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which outcomes are improved by different exercise interventions, including walking, and to assess the evidence quality for each intervention in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise combined with strength training improved aerobic capacity, physical function, and fatigue, while strength training alone improved erythrocyte sedimentation rate and 50-foot walking time. Walking was not specifically highlighted, but the study concluded that any exercise is better than no exercise for RA patients.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 6-week multimodal intervention could alter dynamic anterior pelvic tilt (APT) during walking gait, improve hamstring flexibility, and enhance trunk endurance.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in APT during gait, increased hamstring flexibility, and improved trunk endurance in flexion, extension, and side bridge tests compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 35 active healthy males

study_goal: To determine if eccentric exercise was effective, safe, and feasible in improving walking capacity, quality of life, leg strength, and fatigue in people with heart failure compared to usual care and a waitlist control group.
results_summary: Intention-to-treat analysis showed no significant differences between eccentric exercise, concentric exercise, or waitlist control for any outcome. Per-protocol analysis found modest improvements in quality of life for eccentric exercise compared to concentric exercise, but no major adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 47 participants (16 female; mean age 66 years) with mild to moderate heart failure.

study_goal: To determine the effect of overground walking using a powered exoskeleton on soft tissue body composition in persons with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Participants significantly lost total body fat mass (-1.8±1.2kg, P=.004), with six of eight participants losing visceral adipose tissue (trending toward significance, P=.06). Lean mass remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Persons (N=8) with chronic (>6mo) SCI between 18 and 65 years old who weighed less than 100 kg.
effective_dosage: 40 sessions, each lasting up to 2 hours, 3 times per week.
study_duration: Approximately 13 weeks (40 sessions at 3 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of trunk training on muscle activation patterns, synergies, and motor unit recruitment during walking in sub-acute stroke patients.
results_summary: Trunk training did not significantly alter muscle activation patterns or the number of muscle synergies but improved selective control and endurance of trunk musculature, with decreased fast-twitch motor recruitment in the erector spinae muscles.
population_specificity: Forty-five adults diagnosed with first stroke within five months (39 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 16 hours of trunk training (1 hour, 4 times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify independent features from spatiotemporal data of poststroke gait to improve rehabilitation planning.
results_summary: The study found three independent components explaining 81.9% of variance in poststroke gait data, related to walking speed, temporal asymmetry, and temporal variability, which are useful for rehabilitation strategies.
population_specificity: 69 subacute poststroke inpatients able to walk 10 m without assistance.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to diagnose and treat a rare case of benign metastasizing leiomyoma (BML) in a patient presenting with difficulty in walking due to thigh and lung tumors.
results_summary: The study found that the patient's tumors were diagnosed as BML, and treatment with a gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist led to a 30% regression in tumor size. Walking difficulty was a symptom but not a focus of intervention.
population_specificity: A 48-year-old woman with a history of uterine leiomyoma and surgical interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and safety of a Traditional Chinese Medicine pulmonary rehabilitation (PD) programme compared to exercise and usual activities in improving exercise tolerance and health-related quality of life in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: The PD programme significantly increased the 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) compared to exercise and control groups, with clinically meaningful differences observed at 2 and 6 months. No significant changes were found in health-related quality of life scores, dyspnoea scores, or lung function measures.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
effective_dosage: PD programme: two times a day, 5 days/week for 2 months; Exercise group: 30 min/day, 5 days/week for 2 months.
study_duration: 2 months of intervention, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of VR-based balance training versus conventional balance training in improving balance and reducing falls in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Both VR-based and conventional balance exercises improved balance and mobility in PwMS, with VR-based training showing better efficacy in enhancing cognitive-motor function and reducing falls, while conventional exercises improved directional control more effectively.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS, N=39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence supporting the use of combined nutrition and structured exercise in patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found conflicting results regarding the effects of combined structured exercise and nutrition on exercise capacity, with only one trial reporting quality of life measures and another showing increased blood flow with inorganic nitrate and exercise. There was insufficient data to determine effects on revascularization surgery outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) suffering from intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the association between visuospatial neglect (VSN) and balance/mobility outcomes, including walking, in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that stroke survivors with VSN showed lateral deviations while walking, but results were inconclusive regarding other aspects of mobility. The association between VSN and balance/mobility appeared to decrease over time.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (4,595 participants, with at least 1,319 showing symptoms of VSN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal vibration frequency (20 Hz vs. 25 Hz) and duration (12 weeks vs. 20 weeks) of side-alternating vibration therapy for improving mobility and health parameters in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. It will evaluate mobility, body composition, muscle strength, and other health outcomes after vibration therapy.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 years with cerebral palsy (GMFCS level I-III) who can understand instructions and stand safely.
effective_dosage: 9 minutes per day, 4 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the neurophysiological mechanisms of electrical stimulation and how BCI-controlled FES can improve motor function in rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study suggests that FES can induce neurophysiological changes and restore voluntary movement in individuals with neurological injuries, especially when synchronized with cortical commands via BCI.
population_specificity: Individuals with neurological injuries

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether increased peripheral muscle fatigability in COPD patients affects exercise tolerance, particularly during walking.
results_summary: The study found that while quadriceps fatigability is increased in COPD patients during localized and cycling exercises, it is not consistently observed during walking, likely due to respiratory constraints overshadowing muscle impairments. Pulmonary rehabilitation showed positive effects on muscle fatigability.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether financial incentives could increase daily walking steps among physically inactive, community-dwelling adults in Japan.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significantly higher increase in daily steps during the incentive period compared to controls (1650 vs. 514 steps, p<0.001), but this difference disappeared after incentives were removed. A higher proportion of intervention participants achieved a ≥1000-step increase (69.4% vs. 30.6%).
population_specificity: Physically inactive, community-dwelling adults (mean age 61.2±16.2 years, 69.4% women) from Sendai, Japan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (financial incentive was shopping points for meeting step targets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of aquatic therapy, including walking, in supporting stroke recovery compared to no intervention and land-based interventions.
results_summary: Aquatic therapy was found to be effective in improving walking, balance, and other stroke-induced disabilities, with superior effectiveness compared to land-based interventions in several areas, though aquatic treadmill walking was the least effective method.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (N = 961 across 28 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review interventional strategies for improving gait among stroke survivors in India.
results_summary: The review identified active task-based gait training and strengthening with motor priming as the most tested interventions, showing improvements in gait parameters such as velocity and functional ambulation. Future studies should target both impairment and function for maximum gait improvement.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors in India with gait deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of elastic tape versus placebo tape on reducing low back pain and improving physical function (including walking speed) in pregnant women.
results_summary: Elastic tape significantly reduced lower back pain (29.4% immediately, 75.4% after one week) and disability scores compared to placebo. Both elastic and placebo tapes improved walking speed, but neither significantly affected posture.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with low back pain (n=40, split into two groups of 20 each).
effective_dosage: Application of stretched (elastic group) or non-stretched (placebo group) Kinesio tape to the lower back area.

study_goal: To assess the effect of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on gross motor function in adolescent and adult patients with bilateral spastic cerebral palsy (CP) and compare it with conventional kinesiotherapy.
results_summary: RAGT showed statistically significant and large improvements in all gross motor function dimensions compared to conventional therapy, with effects persisting 3-4 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: Adolescent and adult patients (mean age 21.2±5.33 years) with bilateral spastic CP.
effective_dosage: 20 therapeutic units (specific duration per unit not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (20 therapeutic units administered).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of walking promotion strategies on physical activity, pain, and function in people with musculoskeletal disorders.
results_summary: Walking promotion did not significantly increase physical activity levels compared to minimal interventions but showed small improvements in pain and function versus minimal intervention and usual care. No difference in adverse events was observed between walking promotion and control conditions.
population_specificity: People with musculoskeletal disorders (n = 1456 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if training people with Parkinson's and freezing of gait (FoG) to increase preparatory weight-shift amplitude could facilitate step initiation during FoG events.
results_summary: The study found that both verbal instruction and movement analogies significantly increased weight-shift amplitude, reducing unsuccessful step initiation attempts in the FoG-F group. Hypometric weight-shifting was linked to step initiation failure, but the impairment was modifiable through conscious strategies.
population_specificity: Thirty-five people with Parkinson's disease and freezing of gait (FoG), divided into FoG-F (freeze-induced) and FoG-NF (voluntarily stopped) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three different cognitive-motor training interventions, including walking exercises, on physical activity, life-space mobility, and spatial orientation in nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study expects the PROfit orientation intervention to be most effective in improving physical activity, life-space mobility, and spatial orientation due to increased cognitive-motor capacity and spatial training benefits. The PROfit plus group is anticipated to outperform the PROfit basic group in enhancing physical and cognitive parameters.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents in Germany with declining mobility and cognitive abilities.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 45 minutes each session.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of implementation intentions as an intervention strategy to promote walking in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The intervention group showed a statistically significant increase in leisure-time physical activity and a significant decrease in waist circumference compared to the control group, but no significant differences were observed in body mass index or glycated hemoglobin.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) recruited from primary health care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association of oral hypofunction (OHF) with physical characteristics and function, and test the effects of a combined oral and physical exercise program (COPE-TeL) on oral and physical function in older adults with OHF.
results_summary: The study found that older adults with OHF had significantly lower physical function (e.g., walking speed) at baseline. The COPE-TeL program significantly reduced the proportion of participants with OHF in the intervention group (from 56% to 26%), but not in the control group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with or without oral hypofunction (OHF).
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included comprehensive oral and physical exercises and textured lunch gatherings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of ankle-foot orthoses and functional electrical stimulation in improving walking speed and balance in stroke survivors with foot-drop.
results_summary: Both ankle-foot orthoses and functional electrical stimulation significantly improved walking speed compared to no intervention/placebo, but effects on balance were inconclusive. No significant difference was found between the two interventions for improving walking speed or balance.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults after stroke with foot-drop.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the clinical effects of aquatic activity (walking in water) on chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) compared to no treatment.
results_summary: Aquatic activity significantly improved clinical status and quality of life in CVI patients, with a 4-point reduction in venous severity scores at 3 months (28% in the aquatic group vs. 3% in controls) and sustained benefits at 24 months. Secondary outcomes, including physical health and symptom scores, also showed marked improvements.
population_specificity: 201 patients with advanced chronic venous insufficiency.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 15 minutes of walking in a swimming pool at 1 m/s, 3 times per week.
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, with follow-up to 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if functional treadmill testing (FTT) could differentiate outcomes between operative and nonoperative treatments for adult symptomatic lumbar scoliosis (ASLS) and assess walking-related functional improvements.
results_summary: Operative treatment showed greater improvement in time ambulated, pre-FTT back and leg pain, and post-FTT pain severity compared to nonoperative treatment at 2-year follow-up, though both groups improved in post-FTT pain.
population_specificity: Adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis (ASLS) (187 patients: 88 nonoperative, 99 operative).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was surgical or non-surgical treatment, not a dosage).

study_goal: The study does not address Walking; it focuses on pustular psoriasis and its subtypes (GPP, PPP, ACH).
results_summary: The study does not examine Walking; it discusses the clinical presentation, severity, and management of pustular psoriasis.
population_specificity: Patients with pustular psoriasis (GPP, PPP, ACH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the efficacy and safety of cardiac shock wave therapy (CSWT) in treating coronary heart disease (CAD), including its impact on walking performance (6MWT).
results_summary: Meta-analyses showed significant improvements in 6MWT, NYHA functional class, SAQ score, CCS angina class, and other indicators, suggesting CSWT may benefit CAD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (total n=855, with 781 receiving CSWT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of peripheral blood-derived stem cells (PBDSCs) transplantation, specifically comparing purified CD34+ cells (PCCs) and non-purified peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMNCs), for treating no-option angiitis-induced critical limb ischemia (NO-AICLI).
results_summary: The study found that PBDSCs transplantation significantly improved major amputation-free survival (94.4% at 5 years), wound healing, rest pain, pain-free walking time, ankle-brachial index, transcutaneous oxygen pressure, and quality of life, with no significant differences between PCCs and PBMNCs groups. No critical adverse events were observed, and clinical benefits were durable over long-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with no-option angiitis-induced critical limb ischemia (NO-AICLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Inspiratory Muscle Training (IMT) based on the anaerobic threshold (AT) could better preserve functional capacity and inspiratory muscle strength in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) compared to conventional IMT.
results_summary: The study found that IMT based on AT resulted in significantly less reduction in inspiratory muscle strength (11±10 cmH2O vs. 23±13 cmH2O) and walking distance (57±30 meters vs. 94±34 meters) compared to conventional IMT, indicating better preservation of functional capacity and muscle strength.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), mean age 61.4±10 years, 64% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a cardiac rehabilitation program, including walking sessions, on functional capacity and waist-to-hip ratio in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that the 12-week walking intervention significantly improved functional capacity (measured by the 6-minute walk test) and reduced waist-to-hip ratio in CAD patients compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Coronary artery disease (CAD) patients (n=70).
effective_dosage: Walking sessions at home at least three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the 1-year effects and feasibility of aerobic interval training (AIT), specifically walking/running, in collaborative care for outpatients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that AIT delivered with adherence support in collaborative care was feasible for outpatients with schizophrenia, though specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The intervention involved walking/running at ~90% of peak heart rate.
population_specificity: Outpatients with schizophrenia spectrum disorders (48 participants, 28 men and 20 women, aged 30-41 years).
effective_dosage: 4 × 4 minutes of walking/running at ~90% of peak heart rate (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the need for a holistic rehabilitation approach for dystonia, addressing both motor and non-motor symptoms, including walking impairments.
results_summary: The study found that people with dystonia, particularly cervical dystonia, experience reduced postural control, walking speed, and increased fear of falling, along with non-motor symptoms like pain and fatigue, suggesting a need for comprehensive rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals with isolated forms of dystonia, primarily cervical dystonia, and focal hand dystonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of gait training using the Welwalk rehabilitation robot in improving walking ability in hemiparetic stroke patients in a real clinical setting.
results_summary: The study found that gait training using Welwalk significantly improved the efficiency of walking ability (measured by FIM-walk) compared to conventional rehabilitation, with no significant differences in other outcomes between the groups.
population_specificity: Hemiparetic stroke patients
study_duration: Mean gait training period was 5 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a home-based walk-bike intervention in IPF patients and explore its effects on quality of life and exercise capacity.
results_summary: The walk-bike showed a tendency towards improving health-related quality of life but no effect on exercise capacity. A clinically important difference was observed in the 6-minute walk test with the walk-bike compared to the standard test.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether electromechanical- and robot-assisted gait training improves walking ability after stroke compared to normal care.
results_summary: The study found that electromechanical-assisted gait training combined with physiotherapy significantly increased the odds of participants achieving independent walking and improved walking velocity, though it did not enhance walking capacity. Non-ambulatory individuals benefited most, while ambulatory individuals saw little to no benefit.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years diagnosed with stroke of any severity, at any stage, in any setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the deficits in paretic limb propulsion after stroke and discuss emerging diagnostic and treatment approaches to improve walking rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study highlights that impaired propulsion in the paretic limb contributes to walking disability post-stroke, and current rehabilitation paradigms often fail to restore normal propulsion, leading to compensatory strategies that hinder recovery of efficient gait. Emerging diagnostic and treatment approaches may offer new ways to target propulsion restoration.
population_specificity: Individuals with acquired neuromotor injuries, specifically post-stroke hemiparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess physical function decline, including walking ability, in older people living with HIV (PLHIV) on antiretroviral treatment in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: The study found that nearly 30% of participants had low physical performance (measured via SPPB), with walking-related difficulties (e.g., climbing stairs, walking one block) significantly associated with poor SPPB scores. Factors like age ≥60, female sex, abdominal obesity, and longer HIV duration were linked to worse physical function.
population_specificity: PLHIV aged ≥50 years on ART for ≥6 months in Côte d'Ivoire and Senegal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding non-invasive ventilation (NIV) to long-term oxygen therapy during a 6-minute walk test (6MWT) improves oxygen saturation in patients with interstitial lung diseases (ILDs).
results_summary: The study found that combining NIV with oxygen therapy during exercise increased average oxygen saturation (SaO₂) compared to oxygen therapy alone, suggesting beneficial effects for patients with ILDs.
population_specificity: 16 patients with various interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) who were prescribed oxygen therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used the patient's regular oxygen flow during daily activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate plantar pressure, footwear adherence, and plantar foot ulcer recurrence in people with Charcot midfoot deformity during walking.
results_summary: The study found that people with Charcot midfoot deformity had higher barefoot midfoot peak pressures but effective offloading with custom-made footwear, along with high adherence. However, ulcer recurrence remained high, particularly for midfoot ulcers in the Charcot group.
population_specificity: People with diabetes, Charcot midfoot deformity, and a history of plantar foot ulcers, compared to a non-Charcot foot group with similar ulcer risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify distinct clinical phenotypes of idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) patients and assess their response to therapy, including changes in 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study identified three clusters of IPAH patients with differing clinical presentations, responses to therapy, and survival rates. Cluster 1 (younger, fewer comorbidities) showed better treatment response and survival compared to Clusters 2 and 3, which had older patients with more comorbidities and poorer outcomes.
population_specificity: 841 patients with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH).

study_goal: To evaluate whether multiple sessions of tDCS paired with aerobic exercise improve walking functions in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The active tDCS group showed significant improvements in gait speed and distance covered during walking tests, with benefits persisting at 4-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis patients with neurologic disability (median EDSS 5.5).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions (5 d/wk for 2 weeks) of tDCS (2.5 mA) paired with 20-minute unloaded cycling.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 4 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of passive and post-exercise heat acclimation strategies by directly heating the skin with a water-perfused suit.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effectiveness of the heat acclimation protocols.
population_specificity: Nineteen young males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impacts of under-researched forms of exercise, including walking, on arterial stiffness and endothelial function.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for walking but suggests that habitual physical exercise, including mainstream modes like walking, is advocated to combat arterial dysfunction.
population_specificity: Humans (general population, not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of vericiguat on improving physical limitations (measured by KCCQ PLS) and walking distance (6-minute walk test) in patients with HFpEF.
results_summary: Vericiguat at 15-mg/d and 10-mg/d dosages did not significantly improve the KCCQ PLS or 6-minute walking distance compared to placebo after 24 weeks. Adverse events like symptomatic hypotension and syncope were slightly higher in the vericiguat groups.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic HFpEF (LVEF ≥45%), NYHA class II-III symptoms, recent decompensation, and elevated natriuretic peptides.
